TEXT.value: IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA IN AND FOR THE COUNTY

CONC.value: ) In the Matter of the Estate No.
7800 Dept. 2
) - of - ORDER SETTLING FINAL ACCOUNT
) OF EXECUTRIX AND DECREE OF ANNIE
E. HART DISTRIBUTION )
) - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Now comes Nancy E.
Daley, executrix of the Last Will and Testament of Annie E. Hart,
deceased, by Frederick E. Stone, her Attorney, and proves to the
satisfaction of the Court that her final account and petition for
distribution herein was rendered and filed the 8th day of July, A.D.,
1942, and that the Clerk thereupon appointed the 20th day of July,
A.D., 1942, for the settlement and hearing thereof; that due and legal
notice of the time and place of said settlement and hearing has been
given as required by law; that said account and petition are now
presented to the Court and no person appearing to except to or contest
said account or petition, the Court, after hearing the evidence, finds
that notice to creditors has been duly given as required by law: that
all of the allegations of said petiton are true; that no inheritance
taxes became due and payable to the State of California or the Federal
Government by reason of the death of said Annie E. Hart, deceased, and
that all of the expenses of administration and the expenses of the
last illness of said deceased have been paid; that said account should
be settled and distribution order as prayed for;

TEXT.value: IT IS THEREFORE ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED by the Court that notice

CONC.value: to creditors has been duly given and published as required by law and
that said executrix has in her possession, belonging to said estate,
after deducting credits to which she is entitled, a balance of cash on
hand in the sum of Eight Hundred Eighty-nine and 59/100 ($889.59(
Dollars; personal property consisting of an undivided one-third
interes in and to an undivided 5/2560th interest in and to an oil
royalty of the appraised value of Four Hundred ($400.00) Dollars and
real property located in Los Angeles County, California, of an
appraised value of Three Hundred Fifty ($350.00) Dollars; that said
account be allowed and settled accordingly; That all of the devisees
and legatees and heirs at law of the said Annie E. Hart, deceased,
executed an assignment of all of their right, title and interest in
and to that certain parcel of property owned by the estate described
as undivided 5/2560th interest in and to all oil, gas and other
minerals produced from the following described land in Oklahoma
County, State of Oklahoma, to-wit: The Southeast quarter of Section
26, Township 11 North, Range 3 West, of the Indian Meridian,
consisting of 160 acres more or less. Assigning and transferring the
same to Kathryn Edith Hart which said assignment is on file herein and
proved; IT IS FURTHER ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED that the entire
estate of said deceased whether now known and hereafter described or
whether hereafter discovered or wheresoever the same may be situate or
in which said deceased at the time of her death had any right, title
or interest should be and the same is hereby distributed as follows,

TEXT.value: To Kathryn Edith Hart whose address is P. O. Box 122, Kingman,

CONC.value: Arizona: An undivided 5/2560th interest in and to all the oil, gas and
other minerals produced on the following described land situated in
Oklahoma County, State of Oklahoma, to-wit: The Southwest quarter of
Section 26, Township 11 North, Range 3 West, of the Indian Meridian,
containing 160 acres more or less which was appraised at --- $400.00
All the rest, residue and remainder of said estate to the following
persons in the following amounts, to-wit: To ...., whose address is
Route 5, Box 255, East Bakersfield, California, an undivided one-ninth
(1/9); To Martin G. Hart, whose address is Route 4, Box 444,
Bakersfield, California, an undivided one-ninth (1/9); To A. A. Hart,
whose address is Route 3, Box 206, Bakersfield, California, an
undivided one-ninth (1/9); To M. O. Hart, whose address is Route 5,
East Bakersfield, California, an undivided one-ninth (1/9); To Moses
M. Hart, whose address is Taft, California, an undivided one-ninth
(1/9); To Norma C. Hoag, whose address is 110 North Broadway, Fresno,
California, an undivided one-ninth (1/9); To Emma A. Gleason, whose
address is 2519 M Street, Bakersfield, California, an undivided
one-ninth (1/9); To Nancy E. Daley, whose address is 220 Western
Avenue, Porterville, California, an undivided one-ninth (1/9); To
Kathryn Edith Hart, whose address is P. O. Box 122, Kingman, Arizona,
an undivided one-thirty-sixth (1/36); To Elmer Hart, whose address is
Box 374, Needles, East Bakersfield, California, an undivided one-
thirty-sixth (1/36); To Kenneth Hart, whose address is Boulder City,
Nevada, an undivided one- thirty-sixth (1/36);

TEXT.value: To Gladys Hart, whose address is P. O. Box 122, Kingman, Arizona, an

CONC.value: undivided one- thirty-sixth (1/36); All of the property of said estate
consisting of the residue thereof distributed in undivided portions to
the above heirs in the above fractional interests is described as
follows, to-wit: REAL PROPERTY PARCEL NO. 1: Lots 620, 621, 622 and
623 of the Farthmann Tract in the County of Los Angeles, State of
California as per map thereof recorded in Book 7, Page 158 of Maps,
records of said County which was appraised at Two Hundred ($200.00)
Dollars. PERSONAL PROPERTY Balance of the cash in the sum of Eight
Hundred Sixty-five and 05/100 ($865.05) Dollars now in the hands of
said executrix after deducting therefrom the costs of closing said
estate. Dated: July 20, 1942. Glenn L. Moran Judge of the Superior
Court Filed Tulare County Jul 20 11:19 AM '42 Gladys Stewart By Ann
Hass Deputy

TEXT.value: IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF CALIFORNIA IN AND FOR THE

CONC.value: COUNTY OF TULARE --oOo- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
) In the Matter of the
Estate No. 7800 Dept. 2
) - of - ORDER SETTLING FINAL ACCOUNT
) OF EXECUTRIX AND DECREE
OF ANNIE E. HART DISTRIBUTION
) Deceased.
settling the final account of the executrix and a decree of
distribution having been duly made and entered herein on the 20th day
of July, 1942, which said decree of the distribution described the
assets of paid estate and it appearing that parcel 2 of the real
property as described in said decree as follows: Lots 18 and 19 of the
Diller Tract in the City of Watts, County of Los Angeles, State of
California, as per map recorded in Book 5, Page 180 of Maps, records
of said County of Los Angeles. And it appearing from said lots so
described in said parcel 2 of real property there should have been
excepted that portion of lot 119 lying outside of the boundaries of
the twenty-three acre tract conveyed by Daniel Schieck and wife
William Diller by Deed dated January 3, 1899, recorded in Book 1271,
Page 302 of Deeds and it further appearing that a certified copy of
said decree of distribution was recorded on July 24, 1942, in Book
19436 at Page 272 of Official Records, County of Los Angeles, State of
California. NOW THEREFORE, it is ordered, adjudged and decreed that
the decree of distribution heretofore made and entered herein on the
20th day of July, 1942, be amended and that the description of parcel
2 of the real property in said decree be amended and corrected to read
as follows: PARCEL 2: Lots 118 and 119 of the Diller Tract, in the

TEXT.value: Family Record of Isaac and Annie E. Hart Isaac Hart and Annie E.

CONC.value: Hart, (Butts) were married October 28th, 1870, by Squire Wiggins in
Tehachapi, California. (In the old town of Tehachapi) Isaac Hart, Born
Jan. 6, 1836, Died March 2, 1916, Burried in Bakersfield Annie Eliza
Hart, Born Nov. 28, 1841, Died Feb. 13, 1940, Burried " Josiah Houston
Hart, Born Oct. 23, 1871, Cynthia T. Hart, Born July 31, 1873, Died
Nov. 24, 1888, Burried, Bear Valley, Isaac Newton Hart, Born May 5,
1875, Died Oct. 9, 1931, buried Kingman, Ariz. James M. Hart, Born Jan
23, 1877, Died Oct 18, 1885, burried Bear Valley Martin Green Hart
Born Feb 17, 1879, Died Jan. 25, 1952. " Bakersfield, Calif. Nancy E.
Hart, " March 4, 1881, Died Dec. 14, 1956 Myron Chester Hart, March 7,
1884, Died Dec. 21, 1956 Norma C. Hart, Born Jan. 28, 1886 Emma Annie
Hart, Born April 29, 1888, died May 11, 1956 Aaron Alexander Hart,
born Jan 25, 1891, died July 16, 1967, buried Bakersfield Moses
McKenzie Hart, Born Jan. 25, 1891, Died Oct. 19, 1968 Note: Isaac
Hart's father is also burried in Bear Valley, near Tehachapi, Kern
County, California. P. S. Guess that is the way to spell Moses'
middle name. Typed by Edna N. Hart.

TEXT.value: handwritten on back: Isaac Hart and Annie Eliza Butts were married in

CONC.value: the year 1870, 28th day of October, by Squire Wiggins Isaac Hart was
born Jan. 6, 1836 on line of Arkansas and Indiana Annie E. Hart, Born
Nov. 28, 1851 near Independence, Mo. Josiah Huston Hart was Born Oct.
23, 1871 in Bear Valley near Tehachapi Cynthia Tennessee Hart was
Born July 31, 1873 in Bear Valley near Tehachapi Isaac Newton Hart was
Born May 5, 1875 in Bear Valley near Tehachapi James Monroe Hart was
Born Jan 23, 1877 in Bear Valley near Tehachapi Martin Greene Hart was
Born Feb 17, 1879 on west end Bear Mt. Kern Co. Nancy E. Hart was born
March 4, 1881 in Bear Valley near Tehachapi Myron Chester Hart was
born March 7, 1884 in Bear Valley near Tehachapi Norma Catherine Hart
was Born Jan. 28, 1886 in Bear Valley near Tehachapi Emma Annie Hart
was Born April 29, 1888 in Bear Valley near Tehachapi Aaron Alexander
Hart, born Jan 25, 1891 in Bear Valley Moses McKenzie Hart, Born Jan.
25, 1891 Cynthia Hart died Nov. 14, 1888 in Bear Valley James Hart
died Oct. 18, 1885 in Bear Valley Isaac Hart died Mar. 2, 1916 in San
Joaquin Hosp. Bakersfield Isaac Newton Hart died Oct 9, 1931 in
Kingman Ariz. Annie E. Hart died Feb. 13, 1940 in Porterville M. Green
Hart died Jan 25, 1952 in hosp. at Lancaster, Calif.

TEXT.value: Chronister, Benjamin Franklin b. 1877, LaPorte, LaPorte Co., Ind.

CONC.value: Volunteered at Michigan City, LaPorte Co. Ind., 29Jun1898 161 Reg't
Indiana Infantry. Medical discharge 1899 gave Cornelius Chronister as
relative in case of emergency living in Ottowa, Franklin Co., Kansas
Father George F. Chronister was apparently in Missouri prior to Jul
1888, "Daughter Mina was born 7/16/1888" George was born in Michigan
Mother Anna Bickle born in Indiana

CONC.value: DALEY JAMES E

TEXT.value: DALEY JAMES 94 1916 DEC 26,27
Tulare County, California Death Certificate Transcription: Name:

CONC.value: James Edwin DALEY Date of Birth: August 22, 1823 Place of Birth: New
York Date of Death: December 25, 1916 at 10 p.m. at the age of 93
Years, 4 Months/ & 3 Days Place of Death: Porterville, Tulare Co., CA
Social Security Number: # Veteran ? Sex: Male Color or Race: Caucasian
Single, Married, Widowed or Divorced: Married Name of Husband or Wife:
Mary Ann Curry Usual Occupation: Retired Rancher Industry: Father's
Name: Pardon DALEY Father's Place of Birth: unknown Mother's Maiden
Name: unknown Mother's Place of Birth: unknown Informant: Mrs. J.M.
Hicks (daughter aka Lottie Wesley Daley) Informant's Address: 2240
Thomas Avenue in Fresno, CA Usual Residence of Deceased: Immediate
Cause of Death: La Grippe followed by Bronchial Pneumonia Due To:
Extreme Age by Dr. Higgins Due To: Other Conditions: Burial, Cremation
or Removal: Burial Place of Burial: Porterville Cemetery in
Porterville, Tulare Co., CA Date of Burial: December 27, 1916 Funeral
Home: W. J. Murray of Porterville, CA Transcribed by H. Neil Smith

TEXT.value: ----- Original Message ----- From: "Tim Daley" <Tim.Daley@ccci.org>

CONC.value: To: "Frances Burruss (E-mail)" <fburruss@bak.rr.com> Sent: Friday,
March 12, 2004 10:15 AM Subject: Nancy Hart I notice in my records,
that there is another Nancy Hart. Maybe you can clear up my doubts. I
show: 1)Isaac Riley Hart, b. 6 Jan 1836, d,2 Mar 1916, This is my
greatgrandfather. m. 28 Oct 1870 2) Annie Elizabeth Butts My
greatgrandmother children: 3) Josiah Houston, b, 23Oct 1871 This
is my grandfather 4) Cynthia Tennesse, b. 21 Jul 1873 5) Isaac Newton,
b. 5 May 1875 6) James Monroe, b. 23 Jan 1877 7) Martin Greene, 17 Feb
1879 8) Nancy Elizabeth, 4 Mar 1881 9) Myron Chester, 7 Mar 1884 10)
Norma Catherine, b. 28 Jan 1886 11) Emma Annie, b. 29 Apr 1888 12)
Aaron Alexander, b. 25 Jan 1891 13) Moses McKenzie, b. 25 Jan 1891 3)
Josiah Houston Hart, b. 23 Oct 1871 m. 14) Sarah Fowler - Josiah
Hart's first wife. They didn't have any children. Grace Joy
Harris - Second wife. 15) Raymond Houston Hart b. 28 May 1911 16)
William Isaac Hart b. 29 Jun 1914 17) Nancy Elizabeth Hart b. 4 March
1916 Mamie Ellen Hart b. 4 May 1917 death 30 Oct 1918 I'm
the oldest child of William Isaac Hart b. 29 June 1914 d. 27 Jan 1995
Wife- Elsie France Allen b. 9 May 1917 Elise
Frances "Frankie" Hart b. 4 March 1940 William Isaac Hart Jr. b. 26
Nov 1946 d. 17 Jan 1994 Joan Avon Hart b. 11 May 1949

TEXT.value: The Burris you inquired about was married to Miles Hart b. 1731 in PA.

CONC.value: Her name was Delilah Rice Burris b. 1729 in VA. He is my
gggggrandfather. I will go back on my direct line. William Isaac
Hart, Josiah Houston Hart, Isaac Riley Hart, Josiah Houston Hart Jr.,
Josiah Hart, Miles H. Hart, Thomas Hart, John Hart, and last but not
least Christopher Hart Born in England. I think I have you beat for
the length of time I've been doing genealogy. I've been working on
the for about thirty two years. I've done lot on line with Ancestry
but I still do all my research to make sure it's right. I have some
Daley's in my family are you one of them? Tim I would be happy to
send you any information I have. I hope this helps. Bye for now
Frankie As you can see I have very little info on Josiah and his
family, including you. Also, is 8) Nancy the same as 17) Nancy, but
just misplaced? I also have an Adah Lucille Hart daughter of Aaron
Alexander Hart and Edna M. Lowe who married a Burris(sp?). Any
relation? Or is this more bad information? Have you actually started
into genealogy? I started over 25 years ago with my dad, Marshall, but
haven't had a lot of time to really pursue things. Now that I'm on the
east coast it's even harder to do much research.

PLAC.value: San Jose, Santa Clara, California, USA

TEXT.value: Yates Publishing. U.S. and International Marriage Records, 1560-1900

CONC.value: [database online]. Provo, Utah: MyFamily.com, Inc., 2004. Original
data: This unique collection of records was extracted from a variety
of sources including family group sheets and electronic databases.
Originally, the information was derived from an array of materials
including pedigree charts, family history articles, queries, letters,
Bible records, wills, biographies, and manuscript genealogies. For
specific original source information contact Yates Publishing,
providing them with the Source Number, Source Type, Number of Pages,
and Submitter Code information listed for each individual.

PLAC.value: La Porte, La Porte, Indiana, USA

TEXT.value: Dear Tim, In Caps find the info from the death certificate, in

CONC.value: lower case is the difference in the ledger at the Exeter Cemetary
ANGALINA ESTELLA RAYNOR raynor, angeline e. DATE OF BIRTH - 4-6-1857
PLACE OF BIRTH - LAKE PORT, INDIANA lake point, penn
DATE OF DEATH - 1-28-1934 PLACE OF BURIAL - EXETER, CA DATE OF BURIAL
- 1-30-1934 MOTHER'S MAIDEN NAME - ABBIE ANNA, IND. FATHER'S NAME -
NEWTON GAGE, LAKE PORT, IND. NAME OF OWNER OF PLOT IN CEMENTARY,
L.F.RAYNOR ALSO LISTED AS HUSBAND ON DEATH CERTIFICATE ADDRESS LISTED
AS RESIDENCE AT DEATH - 316 VISALIA ROAD, EXETER, CA LIVED THERE
ABOUT TWO YEARS this was Grandma's address death
certificate was signed by Frances Daley Hope you are feeling better.
Please forward to Dori. Carolyn

TEXT.value: Josiah Hart Texas to California 1852 Josiah had one step-daughter;

CONC.value: step-sister to Martin, Araron, Moses, and Isaac. It is believed that
her name was Tennie Smith and that she had a hotel in Tehachapi. There
were also tow half-brothers to Martin, Aaron, Moses and Isaac who also
came to California on 1852. They were Joe and Dick. Martin came to
Calif with him; was killed by Indians near Walker's basin while
hauling freight by ox team from Los angeles to Havilah. Aaron was
married, had one daughter married to a man named Davenport of
Tehachapi, Calif. They had one son named Milton who was killed in his
earaly teens. Moses was married to Julia Finley. They had ten
children: Jack, Moses, Charles, Riley, William, Edward, Benjamin,
Sarah, Mattie and Emily who died at an early age. Tom and John Hart
were also sons of Josiah but remained in Texas and raised large
families. Joe Hart married Mary Finley; their children were Johny,
Dick, May, Bishop, Maud and Bessie. The memorial park east of
Bakersfield was named in honor of Johny Hart who was a Kern County
supervisor for several years. Dick never married.

9-7-2003, son of Marshall Stockton Daley I assume this was written by

TEXT.value: May, This John Dailey was the son of Mr Daley's counsin & a second

CONC.value: cousin of Marshall, also a full cousin of the late judge Al Hull of
P'ville - latter has been gone about 25 years - Al's wife was Etta
Parker of the White River Parkers, ranch was on the Hot Springs Road
above Fountain Springs. This John lived east of Visalia all his life -
they were good looking & very good people. He was a cousing of my Hall
cousins who grew up in P'ville. Blanche ran a flower shop in Delano
for years - very pretty - then there was Della (I think) - she to me
was handsome - I was just a little kid to them but they always said
"How do you do Ora, and how are you?", smiling most beautifully. They
never ofund out, for they were quite popular & by the time I got my
bashful little tongue ready to answer as to how I was - they -
so-to-speak - had gone on to another and brighter flower - namely my
sister who could dimple & chat & was "pick-up" size. I rarely saw any
of them after my mother passed away.

PLAC.value: Low Town, Parish of Moore, County Roscommon, Ireland
Chapel of the Chimes, Oakland, Alameda County, California

TEXT.value: January 31, 1999 Dear May and Marshall, I promised you I would fill

CONC.value: you in with information of the Daleys. My grandfather's name was
Benjamin Franklin Dailey - born October 7, 1844 in New Yourk. His
parents were Parissa C. and Namcy (O'brien) Dailey. They had more
children named Margaret, Clarissas, George W. ,Ellen M. and Samuel
Pardon Dailey. Parisso C. Daley was born in Canada. Nancy (O'brien)
Daley was born in New York. In the 1850 U. S. Census of Clinton Co.
New York it lists a Pardon Daley age 64 head of household and born in
New York and Lydia Daley age 66 born in New York. The other Daleys
listed in the household and presumed to be children were Martha age 3,
born in new York and James age 25 laborer born in New York. Lydia
Daley died in New York Feb. 10, 1852 and is buried in a cemetery in
Ellenburgh. For the James Daley family the spelling used most
consistently was Daley and for Parissa it was Dailey. James and
Parisso later moved to California. The parisso Dailey family lived in
the Visalia area of California and the James Daley family settled in
Porterville, California. Dr. Ronald Moore - Great grandmother was
Sarah Daley- She married William Moore. The Moores lived for a few
years in the area of Warren County, New York and then moved to
California by wagon in about 1860. The Moores stopped for a while in
Osceola, iowa to visit Sarah's brother James Daley. The Moores lived
in Sacramento and Stanislaus Counties in California. It is believed
that Parisso Dailey came to California about the same time or maybe a
leittle ahead of the William and Sarah (Daley) Moore family but quite
a few years before James Daley mopved to Porterville, Calif. from
Iowa. My mother was Lula Ann Dailey - she was born February 22, 1895
in Exeter, Calif. Whe had sisters Bertha who married Charlie Butts.
They lived in Exeter. Bertha and Charlie had children named Myrtle,
Eva, Margaret, Doris Ruth, Harold, Vernon and Danny Butts.

TEXT.value: Then mother's sister named Ellen married Frank Howard. They lived many

CONC.value: years on Goshen Avenue in Visalia, Calif. They had children named
Bernice, Ben, Mabel, Albert & Alberta twins, Ray, Nellie, Emma and
Ethel. Mother had brothers named George, Daniel and Edward. When
Edward was born he was adopted by his Aunt Ellen (Dailey) Cox who was
a sister to my gradnfather Benjamin Franklin Dailey. As my grandmother
Ruth (Swanson) Dialey - grandpa's wife died during child birth of
Edward (Dailey) Cox. My mother was only w years old at the time. She
was living in various home and also with friends. I remember her
telling me that one time she lived in Fresno. Then in later years
ended up in Visalia. It was there where she met Willaim A. Vollmer. He
had moved there from Minnesota. He had 3 sisters, Mary, Tillie, and
Irene and his mother who had settled in Visalia. They had moved out
there from the southern part of Minnesota. Mother - Lula Ann Dailey-
and father - William A. Vollmer- were married June 24, 1928 in the
First CHurch of God in Visalia Calif. I was born December 12, 1931, in
Modesto, California. Father and mother did a little traveling into
Oregon and Idaho and decided settling on a peach ranch east of
Modesto, Calif. Father owned 20 acres and farmed there. In 1946 he
sold the ranch and in January 1947 we moved into the town of Modesto.
I attended and graduated from Empire Grammar School and Modesto High
School. June 23, 1957 I married Malcolm Balck in Modesto, Calif. He
was born in Des Moines, Iowa. Spent four years in the navy, mostly in
San Diego, Calif. with schedules in Memphis, Tennessee and a while in
Jacksonville, Florida. When discharged he ended up near Hughson,
Calif. and also Lodi, Calif. He attended Modesto Junio College. After
we were married we lived in Davis, Calif. He attended U of C there. I
worked for Mr. Riley, did banking, payroll, sales, etc., at his Davis
store. Helped put Malcolm through College.

TEXT.value: We lived in Davis until Januaray, 1960, then we lived at Lodi,

CONC.value: Stockton and November 1960 we moved to Fresno, Calif. Lived there til
August 1968 and Malcolm being with the State of Calif., Dept. of
Agriculture was transferred to Sacramento. In September 1991, he
retired. We have two daughters Margaret born in September 1960 and
Lynne in October, 1964. Both are married. Margaret is a registered
nurse, lives in Victorville, Calif.and and Lynne works for the State
of Calif. in Sacramento. She lives in Fair Oaks which is only 3 miles
from us here in Citrus Heights. Lynne has one daughter Amanda who is
seven years old. We have enjoyed our grand daughter. She is in second
grade. Seems to be very talented. Learns fast. Already doing
multiplication in school. My mother Lula Ann (Dailey) Vollmer would
mentioned to me (?) about Claude Duncan. I think he might of been a
cousin to her and he lived either in the Springville area or
Porterville. I just can't remember. Also mother had cousins in the
Visalia area. There was an Amanda Swanson and Perry Swanson. I
remember Perry had a cow daisy and years ago we visited an Eva
Swanson. Whe was quite elderly then. Mother belonged to the Neighbors
of Woodcraft the Modesto Circle #443. Malcolm and I belong to the
Sacramento Circle #941 Neighbor of Woodcraft. We used to attend the
social functions in South Sacramento. Enjoyed their bingo. We moved to
Citrus Heights few months abo. Haven't been able to attend but like
getting the Pacific Echo. My uncle Edward and aunt Margaret Cox after
leaving the Visalia area move to Orosi, Calif. to be near their
daughter Ellen Bodley. All are deceased. Malcolm and I attended the
Moore, Dailey, Daley reunion held on November 14, 1998 west of
Patterson, Calif. It was potluck luncheon and program afterward. Must
of been 100 of us in the recreation hall. It was sure good seeing
cousins that I hadn't seen in years. Also met new ones I never knew
existed. One came all the way from Georgia.

TEXT.value: I had met Dr. Ronald Moore at the Daley reunion held in Ceres, Calif

CONC.value: near Modest years ago and saw him and his wife Anne at the Daley-Butts
reunion at Mooney Grove park in Visalia in later years. I was sure
glad Dr. Moore called me on the phone last year, wanted to know if I
would be interested in attending the reunion which they had scheduled
for November 1998. So he sent me the directions. I was glad Malcolm
was able to drive me. We went through some foggy weather conditions
near Stockton and getting over toward Patterson and to where the
recreation hall was located. we had such mountainous and in some
places steep grades to climb that for me would have been hard to deal
with the narrowing road. Mildred Traylor from the Porterville Pomelo
Circle 292 sure must be a nice person. glad she written about you in
the Pacific Echo. I am happy you ansered the phone when I called. It
gives me more of an idea as I related to the Daley families. I think
you do very good for your ages. Would be nice if some day we could see
each other. My cousin Margaret (Butts) Crain lives in Lindsay, Calif.
She is sister to Myrtle (Butts0 Hoover who lives in Woodlake. Usually
myrtle notifies me of the reunion held in Visalia. Myrtle is 85 years
old. Will say best to all. Sincerely, Luella (Vollmer) Black

CONC.value: According to Edna Hart, Isaac & Annie were married by Squire Higgins.

CONT.value: "Charles M. Hart. The father of the immediate subject of this sketch,

CONC.value: Moses Hart, was born in Chickaway, Indian Territory, Dec 1, 1833, and
in 1850 started across the plains with ox teams, arriving in San Jose,
California in 1852. From there he soon moved to Mariposa County, where
he mined until 1856. Later he lived for a time in Los Angeles COunty
whence he came in 1857 to Kern County. Locating in Oak Creek two years
later he became the owner of a ranch of 160 acres and of a quarter
section of railroad land. It is a matter of record that he was one of
the petitioners, in 1865, ofr the organization of Kern County. In
1863, he was in the indian figh in Kelsey Canyon, Kern County, where
he was waylaid by the indians; his brother, Martin and his
step-brother Oliver were both killed July 3, 1863. The father
organized a posse and followed the indians to Owens Rivere where they
attacked the Indians eighteen days later. Nineteen of the Indians were
killed in the battle, the remainder escaping. Mr. Hart married July
15, 1859, Miss Julia Ann Findley, who bore him twelve children. She
passed away January 21, 1907, and his death occurred Dec. 21, 1903.

CONT.value: "It was at Old Town, Tehachapi, that Charles M. Hart was born March

CONC.value: 19, 1870. He attended public school at Tehachapi and in Bear Valley
until he was seventeen years old, when he bravely took up the battle
of life on his own account. He entered the employ of the Santa Fe and
learned the machinist trade at Needles. From 1891 to 1894 he had a
market and butcher business at Jerome, Arizona. In the year last
mentioned he sold out and returned to Kern County and a time lived at
Bakersfield. In 1896 he established himself in the meat business at
Tehachapi but soon sold his market and homesteaded land in the Weed
Patch area and for some time he farmed 1700 acres of land, the greater
part of which he leased. Eventually he disposed of his ranch, moved to
Mohave County, Arizona, and established a meat market at Chloride
which he conducted successfully three years. During the ensuing two
years he was in the same business at Needles, San Bernardino County,
California. Then, disposing of his interests at Needles, he went to
Nevada where he was employed as a master mechanic for the Green Water
Death Valley Mining Company. After eleven months experience there he
came back to Kern County and became the owner of and leasee of mining
land in the Caliente Valley which he operated a short time. In Nov.
1907, he took charge of the department distributing all the meat along
the Los Angeles aqueduct for the butcher trade of the Eressler Meat
Co. of Los Angeles and for a year and a half filled the position of
general manager. Then removing to Lost Hills, Kern County, he opened a
meat market there, of which he has since been proprietor. He owns the
hootel and general store at Hart station, on the stage line two miles
east of Lost Hills and also gives considerable attention to teaming
and contracting, and the buying and selling of stock, hay, and grain.
He has interests in the oil fields, has invested in land in Lost
Hills, but still maintains his home at Wasco. As a democrat Mr. Hart
has been active in local politics and as a delegate he has taken part
in the deliberations of a number of Democratic County conventions and
is serving as deputy sheriff. Fraternally he affiliates with Fraternal
Order of Eagles.

CONT.value: "On April 3, 1900, he married Katherine Watchman, a native of

CONC.value: Pennsylvania, who had come west with her parents, who located at
Cripple Creek, Colo. From there Mr Watchman removed to Cripple Creek,
where he remained until 1896, at which time he located at White Hill,
Mohave County, where for several years he successfully operated a
mine. Thence he removed to Chloride Arizona, where he bought mining
property which he operated until 1907, when he sold it and removed to
Tonopah, Nevada. After living there a year and a half he came to Kern
County and leased a mine near Tehachapi. In 1908 he lived for eight
months at Randsburg, where he operated the Butte mine with
satisfactory results. He then leased the King Solomon mine which he
has since handled with success. Mrs. Hart has borne her husband four
children, Laura J., Daniel C., Thomas M., and Frank M..

Sketch Page (page 341) --
Isaac Hart is one of the first settlers of Bear Valley, Kern County,
California. He was born on the line dividing Arkansas and the Cherokee
January 6, 1836. The following February his father, Josiah Hart, moved
family into the interior of Texas. Josia Hart was a hunter and trapper
followed that occupation for many years. He hunted the buffalo and

CONC.value: antelope in

CONT.value: the Red River Valley as early as 1826, shipped his game down to the

CONC.value: Red river

CONT.value: to market points. He lived in Texas until 1852, when he came to Los
County, California, leased a portion of the Axusa ranch and remained
until 1854, keeping a public "stopping-place." in 1859 he became the
settler of Cumming's Valley, locating the present place of George

CONC.value: Cummings. He

CONT.value: spent the rest of his life in Cummings Valley, dying May 28, 1872. He

CONC.value: was born

CONT.value: in Hardin County, Kentucky, November 18, 1794; was a man of strong
individuality and industrious habits and a born pioneer of the old
Isaac Hart left home at about the age of nineteen years, entered the
land survey and aided in establishing the line between the San
meridian and the Colorado River. He also assisted in correcting the
surveys of Kern and later (1856) San Bernardino and San Diego
He devoted his time to mining in the Kern river country up to about

CONC.value: 1869, when

CONT.value: he located in Bear Valley where he has since resided. He owns 320

CONT.value: agricultural land in Bear Valley and ranges a limited number of

CONC.value: cattle. He, Mr.

"Continuing northward on Hwy. 14, our next stop was at a historic

CONC.value: marker designating the stage stop and weigh station of Lyon's Station,
operated for many years by Sanford Lyon and including a depot, store,
post office, telegraph office and tavern. Before Lyon however, the
pioneer Hart family of the Tehachapi's first operated the station."
"Hart's station was an important stop as early as the Kern River gold
rush of the 1850s, operated by Josiah Hart from 1854 until 1858 when
he moved to Cummings Valley. Hart, born at Hardin County, Kentucky, in
1794, was a frontiersman in the truest sence of the word. His early
years were influenced by the spirit of men like Daniel Boone. In the
early 1820's he hunted buffalo and antelope in the Red River Valley,
shipping game downriver to various markets. Migrating westward from
Texas, he too crossed to El Monte by way of the Southern Trail. Until
his establishment of a public "stopping place" he leased a portion of
Azusa Ranch. Hart's or Lyon's station as it was later known, was
important until the 1870's when the Southern Pacific Railroad reduced
the need for a stage line."

CONT.value: "Bland Field was the home of Californian Tully Bland, who was born in

CONC.value: Los Gatos in 1859, ten years after his parents joined the gold rush to
California. Bland was one of the fabled vaqueros who rode for Miller
and Lux as well as Carr and Higgins, well known San Joaquin Valley
cattlemen. He became a freighter conductor when the railroad came to
Tehachapi, but after two years settled in Bear Valley to raise crops,
stock and children. Bland's wife was Sarah Hart, a daughter of Moses,
who with his brother Isaac (both of them sons of Josiah Hart's) was
also a Bear Valley settler. Isaac first saw the Valley as a member of
the government survey party of 1855 and then spent several years
mining in the Kern River Valley before settling in Bear Valley about
1869. His job with the surveying crew had been marking and building
mounds at the section corners. Moses settled at Oak Creek in the late
1850's and located a farm in Bear Valley in the 1870's.

CONT.value: "In 1875 fifteen land owners had six sections planted in grain. That

CONC.value: year Bear Valley's crops were in a "prosperous state of cultivation,
all the land occupied by families. The farm of F. Fickert has 60 acres
of barley, wheat and oats, commented an observor. Other farmers of the
time were L. Fickert, A. Butts, Mr. Hosac, John Neal, F. Flanagan, Mr.
Hart, J. Glenn, a man called Wilson, T. Martin, J. Hart, E. Calhoun,
Mr. Bigham, N. Hart, and Mr. Smith who altogether had 1,230 acres
planted in grain."

CONT.value: See GenealogyScans\Books\ACaliforniaMiddleBorder - Chapter 11
"When the Fort Tejon was abandoned by the army in 1861, the settlers

CONC.value: were left unprotected from the local indians, particularly in the
Owens Valley there were frequent reports in 1862. By May it was
claimed the indians were in almost "undisputed possession" of the
whole Owens Valley. In Sept. a meeting was held on an island in So.
Fork of Kern River; an "outlaw element" from bands living there, as
well as near Tehachapi, and on the desert, agreed to attack the
settlers in the Owens Valley the following winter and wpring. One
family in Tehachapi, felt the ramification of the spring offensive.
The Hart's from their initial arrival in the mid 1850's in the
Tehachapis, engaged in freighting. While hauling merchandise from L.A.
to Kern River, on July 3, 1863, as they passed thru Kelso Valley,
Martin Hart, Oliver Burke, Moses Hart, Wm. Dawson, and James Hazlum,
were ambushed by a band of about "40 Tehachapis". Martin was killed
with a shot in his head; his step-brother, Oliver Burke was hit
although shot in an arm, returned the fire, killing an indian. Dawson,
carrying the wounded Burke to safety, was fired upon; again Burke was
hit, this time in the side, he asked Dawson to put him down and as he
lay dying, fired once more, but died preparing to shoot again. Moses
Hart, Dawson, and Hazlum decided to abandon their teams and wagons,
and escaped."

CONT.value: See GenealogyScans\Books\ACaliforniaMiddleBorder - Chapter 12
"The search for gold was not without problems. Violence shattered a

CONC.value: camp on Christmas night 1861. Aaron Hart, a son of Josiah and a
chainman in the 1854 governmental survey (as was his brother Isaac),
lived in the valley and prospected for gold. At his home that night a
visitor, P. Lewis accosted another guest, Joel H. Brooks threatening
to shoot Brooks. Hart and another man, David Hart, who was not
related, temporarily settled the disagreement. Ill-feelings continued,
however, until on Jan. 8, they met again on a prospecting trip. This
time Brooks was the aggressor and his gun. As he fired, Lewis used his
pick, pah and shovel for a shield, and avoided the shots, but Aaron
Hart was wounded in the arm. Brooks told Aaron "to go home and when he
got well he would shot him again", which led to furhter arguing, this
time between Lewis and a man called Ayres. Again, as he attempted to
prevent a fight, Aaron was shot. Lewis then stole a horse, saddle and
bridle, and "escaped to the upper country by way of San Pedro".
Meanwhile, Hart's wound mortified and on Jan. 21st, "a respectable man
and very popular in the community" died."

"Tehachapi school district was formed on Nov. 9, 1866, when the board

CONC.value: of supervisors established the boundaries of the first publically tax
supported school district in Kern County. At first classes were
probably held in a private home, as it wasn't until June 27, 1868,
when the school trustees were elected, that the citizens also voted to
build a schoolhouse. A wood frame building was constructed and there
Miss Lavese Maria Jewett instructed her first students, which included
5 Doziers, 5 Wigginses, 4 Brites, (Hart's relatives) 1 Hosack, 4
Cuddlebacks, 3 Tylers, 1 Hale and Nelly Calhoun.

"Moses Hart, of Bear Valley, Kern County, has been a resident of

CONC.value: California since 1852. He first located in San Hose, where he remained
until November, 1853, mined in Mariposa County until 1856, after which
he took up his residence in Los Angeles County. Since 1857 he has
lived in Kern County, having located on his present farm of 160 acres
in 1876. He was one of the petitioners for the organization of the
county in 1865. Besides his home ranch Mr. Hart owns a quarter section
of railroad land, and keeps a band of cattle and horses.

CONT.value: "Isaac Hart is one of the first settlers of Bear Valley, Kern County,

CONC.value: California. He was born on the line dividing Arkansas and the Cherokee
Nation, January 6, 1836. The following February his father, Josiah
Hart, moved his family into the interior of Texas. Josiah Hart was a
hunter and trapper and followed that occupation for many years. He
hunted the buffalo and antelope in the Red River Valley as early as
1826, shipping his game down the Red River to market points. He lived
in Texas until 1852, when he came to Los Angeles County, California,
leased a portion of the Azusa Ranch and remained there until 1854,
when he located at Newhall. At the latter place he resided till 1858,
keeping a public "stopping place." In 1858 he became the first settler
of Cummings Valley, locating the present place of George Cummings. He
spent the rest of his life in Cummings Valley, dying May 28, 1872. He
was born in Hardin County, Kentucky, November 18, 1794; was a man of
strong individuality and industrious habits and born pioneer of the
old times.

newspaper article, 26 December 1916 probably from a Porterville
"Grandpa" Daley died last night at his home - Deceased had distinction

CONC.value: of being Porterville's oldest registered voter

CONT.value: Following a brief illness, James Daley, better known as "Grandpa"

CONC.value: Daley passed away about 10 o.clock last nigh at his home, 222 C

CONT.value: The funeral will be held tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock from the home

CONC.value: of the deseased, 222 South C street. Interment will be in the
Porterville cemeteray. Rev. J. A. Milligan officiating, W, J, Murray
to in (sic) charge of funeral arrangements.

CONT.value: "Grandpa" Daley as he was caled by many, owing to his advanced age was

CONC.value: born August 23, 1823, in Clinton county, New York, his father having
been one of the pioneer settlers of that state when it was yet the
frontier. In ???? he moved from New York to Iowa, where he lived until
coming to California about 26 years ago.

CONT.value: Besides his widow, who was Miss Mary Ann Curry and to whom he was

CONC.value: married in ????. He is survived by eight of his fourteen children born
to their union, those being Mrs. R. M. Millick, Eddie and Edwin
(twins), Frank, Arch, and Walace Daley of this city, a daughter, Mrs.
J. M. Hicks of Fresno and a son Asa resides in Iowa.

CONT.value: The deceased bore the distinction of being Porterville's oldest

CONC.value: registered voter, and of having voted in every presidential election
since he was of Age. He was one of the few who had foted the ??? of
the "Whigs" before they became the Republican party.

CONT.value: Personal conversation between Frances May Daley and Tim Eugene Daley
She listed among the children of James E. Daley as Edwin, Eddie,

CONC.value: Archibald, Franklin, Asa, Samantha, Wallace, Elizabeth (Jenny),
Joseph, and Lottie. She had not heard of a James Wallace, Claire,
Ellen or G. M. (but this might be Mattie)

In January 1971, my brother Cecil Kenney and I, Ruth Kenney Rudisill
were looking through some papers of our cousin, Phil Thibeaudeau. We
found a little note book that looks like the writing of his mother,
Mrs. Cora Brule Thibeaudeau.

CONT.value: Here is what it said:
"Grandpa E Aleczander Butts and wife Grandma Elizabeth Ann Butts left

CONC.value: Independence Missour in 1852 by Ox teem to California the lived about
20 miles from Independence. I dont know just where they lived first in
California they had a little baby girl which was my Aunt Annie the
baby took sick with hooping cough and Grandma gave her mares milk to
cure her. it did.

CONT.value: "their first child born in Calif was uncle Aleck. then I think my

CONC.value: mother was next name Elizabeth Rebecca Butts then Napoleon Boneypart
or it may be he was before mother. he was kiked by a horse and his
spine was badley injured when he was a young boy so he was a cripple
and delicate all his life. I remember him quite well. he was alway so
pleasant and had such a happy spirit but was never able to do much
work of course he was a grown man when I knew him but I dont know how
he made his living I was only a tiny little girl when I knew him.

CONT.value: "My Grandparents was liveing in Napa at the time of mothers birth

CONC.value: which was in 1857 then they lived in Lake county I dont know if that
was before or after mothers birth. There is a canyon in Lake County
named Butts Canyon after Grandpa. I dont know the year they left that
part of Calif. then went down south to Owens valley then at one time
they ran a hotel in Tehaspi (dont know how to spell it) I dont know
where they went from there but when I was a big girl enough to
remember how they looked I guess I was 6-7- or 8 they had home steaded
a place in the mountains above Sonora and Grandma died there from
blood poison from a calf that steped on her foot she let it stand on
till she got it tied it swole up and turned very bad. Grandpa was a
drinking man and was drunk at that time and never got a Dr and she
died a horrible death from blood poison after that he left the place
and went down South in Calif and wandered around one place then a
nother I remember he stayed a coup of days with us on the ranch we
were liveing on 9 miles from Turlock. he was liveing at Tipton down
*M-south takeing care of Irrigating a farm down or an orchard any way
the water was pumped by horse power. and some one saw the horse was
going day and, night and they went to his cabin and 4 him lying on his
bed in his work clothes dead.

CONT.value: "I dont remember where he was burried."
Ruth Rudisill's comments to above:
Paragraph 2.
per 1860 Cenus Clear Lake Township, County of Napa the children born

CONC.value: in Calif. were: James Alexander 6 yrs; DoctOr Salathiel 5 yrs; Rebecca
3 yrs; Napoleon Bonapart 8/12.

CONT.value: Paragrph 3.
a. This is the first time I ever heard Owens Valley mentioned for the

CONC.value: Butts family.

CONT.value: b. We knew part of the Butts family had been in Tehachapi Mts. We have

CONC.value: a letter addressed to my grandmother (Rebecca) Mifs Lissie Butts
Tehachepa, Kern County, Cal. post marked 1876. But did not know the
family ran a hotel there.

CONT.value: c. We also now know that the home steaded property was not above

CONC.value: Sonora but between Mariposa and Raymond, and recently located the
grave. June 4, 1889.

CONT.value: d. Cora Edith (Rebeccao was born May 4, 1880 so if she was 6, 7, or 8

CONC.value: it would have been 1886, 1887, or 1888,

CONT.value: e. Cora's family (Alfred Brule) left that ranch 9 miles from Turlock

CONC.value: about 1898 for Klondike Gold Rush.

CONT.value: September ISUI
Indepomdente Missouri
Dear Brother,
I take the earliest oppertunity of acknowledging the reciept of your

CONC.value: letter of the 18 of June 1848, and was mucb pleased to hear that you
was all well.

CONT.value: We are all in very good health at present ano hope that these few

CONC.value: linees nay find you all enjoying the alike blessing. You wishee me to
let you know how I liked this country. I am well pleased and had
rather live or rented land here than owr in your country.

CONT.value: Father is living with me and is well and doing well. We have lately

CONC.value: heard from Unnessee. the connection are all well and Katherine
Darnel, is dead and Joshua also. Darnel married Jesse Upchurns' widow.
Delaney has had fourteen children. Salathitl NNOM940=404- Butts has
freighted goods to Santa A this year and made about $1500. this year
and is in a fair way to make $500. by wAtering stock. He has lost
sight of everything but money, he can't take time to wright to any
person !RAI divising ways and means to Ap"MRRMW money. Oney matUrs are
very brisk. Cow and calves are worth from $10. to $12., horses and
mules from $40. to CO., NOU

CONT.value: Pork $2., Corn $1. per BBL. wbeat is .504 per Bu.
Flanning Drummond has moved back to this country and is living at the

CONC.value: old place where vy father used to live. he and his family are all well
and send their best respects. Father Baker also sends his best
respects and wnuld be glad to see you all. So no more at present but
remain your affectionate brother and sister.

CONT.value: Joseph and Elender Baker
1 " 1
P.S. Y.
Elizabeth and Quise Jane Baker send their respects to Margaret Ann

CONC.value: Butts. They ha" been going to school nearly all the time since they
came back. Give our best respects to James Lovela4y and family. Ule
would be glad to know if Ann is married.

CONT.value: J. & E. R.

CONT.value: September 1060 or 1852
Jackson County Missouri
Dear Uncle,
It is the mercies of our Kind Father that I have been favored with the

CONC.value: opportunity of writing to you that we are all well at present and
hoping when these few lines come to hand that you and your family may
be enjoying the best

CONT.value: of X11 health.
All of the connections is well and sands their best love and respects

CONC.value: to you and your family.

CONT.value: Father and Uncle Joe Baker started to Santa Fe but they could not make

CONC.value: the trip befbre Spring anad they turned back and they said that money
wtont pay them to cross the Plains where there are so many Indians.
Uncle Joe said Saru Clew Indians.

CONT.value: There has been a great deal of sickness here this spring and summer.

CONC.value: The Colory has been very fatal here. Father had It himself. There has
been a great deal of wet weather here this season. Crops are very good
considering the wet weatber. Corn is worth $1 per barrel, wheat is
part of letter destroyed by age times have been flourishing, good
mules are worth from seventy to one hundred dollars, oxen (good) $40
to $75 apoke, good cows are worth $16 to $25, and plenty of money to
pay for them.

CONT.value: I have been #1 going to school this fall and helping to sow wheat. NOW

CONC.value: Pappaw apples are ripe and Huston is now a possum hunting tonight. The
connections all sends their best love and respects to you and your
family and say that WAY would like to see you.

CONT.value: There has been a few weddings in the family connections. Uncle Henry

CONC.value: and Jane Hawkings, (Hawkins) is all there is home of the rest of them
that wants tto marry as well as myself. We have had a letter from
Uncle Jesse Upchurch, and Omy vas all well.

CONT.value: he Weved a letter from Wry Rawkings in California, he has been there 4

CONC.value: years. His letter gave bery good account of tie country and gold mines
and advises his friends to come and says the route by water is

CONT.value: I am going in the spring if nothing happens. That is my calculations.

CONC.value: I must bring my few lines to a close. If you hear anybody inquiring
for me, give them a copy (of the letter) and tell them to travel.

CONT.value: Wondfather Pau? (?) still likes his tea as usual.
* This letter was written by Levi Butts in Nlissouri, W 6is Uncle

CONC.value: Jackson Butts who was in Victoria, Texas.

CONT.value: * Levi was the son of Salathiel Butts, Jackson Butts is Salathiel's
This is a copy of a copy made from original from Linda Eutts, 8610

CONC.value: Ildica St. Spring Valley, Calif. 92077

CONT.value: Octabor 10, 1854
Jackson County Missouri
Dear Brother,
I take the opportunity to write to you to inform you that we are all

CONC.value: well at Present, hoping when these few lines come to hand they wAy
find you all enjoying the like blessings. Received your letter Utober
the 9th day which I was glad to hear from you all. Yaw wrote to a* to
know where~ rW children was. Levi Butts went to Calif., in the spring
of 1350, and came back this spring with a drove of cattle and
Alexander Huston Butts went to Calif. in the spring of 1152 and he is
living there at this tine and he was well the last time I heard from

CONT.value: him. And you wanted to know where "enry Butts children was. Jany butts

CONC.value: wcnt with Levi Butts to Calif., and Nancy Jane is living with Joseph
Baker and Sarah is living with Drumany.

CONT.value: We have very sorry crops this year. Oe have not had no rain since June

CONC.value: the 16th day, no more than to settle the dust. I have soweJ wheat but
it has not coamn up yet it just lay in the dust. Wheat is MUMA worth
$6.10 per bushel, corn is worth $3.50 per 6ushel, oats is worth $2.00
a hundred corn meal is worth $1.00 per bushel, bacon is worth .08t a
pound. Sutiw ias engaged po,k $5.0 hun6red and

CONT.value: stock is low here, provision all kind will be very high. The govt. has

CONC.value: purchased the Indian land west of the 6oundary line and it is settling
very fast. The roads is alive with wagons steady. I want you to write
to me what sort of country youre living in and what it is good for,
the soil. the climate, ti-4e range and the nealth of your country and
what you raise to make money out of. I have had some notion to

CONT.value: come and see you and look at your country but I dont know when. So I

CONC.value: have nothing more at present to write to you but remain your
affectionate brother until death.

CONT.value: Salatbial Butts

CONT.value: Marrh 30, 1900
Independence Missouri
Dear Sir and Uncle,
I an Elsa daughter of Salathial Butts. I read the letter you wrote to

CONC.value: the party at Independence. I married a man by the name of Hensley. I
am the youngest one of my fathers children. The second time my father
was married he had four children, three boys and myself. Father died
in 1856 and I was borned one month afterward. Too of my brothers are
dead. I have two half brothers and two half sisters livinq. Their
names are; Houston, Jane, Susan, and Napoleon. The sisters married
brothers by the name of Sublett. 4y own brother is John L. Butts, next
youngest to myself. My mother 4ied 14ay 5, 1898. 1 live on the
homestead which my father entered. It belongs to my brother John L.

CONT.value: Levi Butts, my half brother, has been dead about eight years. His

CONC.value: children live in Cass Countty Mo. Josysh Baker has been dead
toenty-five or thirty years, his wife has been dead fifteen years.

1: F Martha DAILY (AFN:1112-8KC) b: Abt 1819 Ellenburgh, Clinton,

CONT.value: According to Ron Moore in the following e-mail, Jacob Daily is not the

CONC.value: father of Pardon Daley

CONT.value: Re: Pardon Daley
From: Ron Moore <rmoore@cybergate.com>
To: timdaley@earthling.net
References: 1
Nice to hear from you again.
I have seen that information on the LDS website before. Some is

CONC.value: accurate and some is not.

CONT.value: The information about Pardon Daley being the son of Jacob and Sarah

CONC.value: Daily is not accurate, in fact I am certain it is false. Jacob Daily
also lived in Clinton County, NY but there is no evidence he was
connected to Pardon Daley. I, some many years ago sent and obtained
his will and there is no mention of Pardon there. I then came to the
conclusion he was of another line and just happened to live in Clinton
County. The father of Pardon Daley I am certain is Samuel Daley who
lived in Washington County, NY. The grandfather of Pardon Daley is
thought to be another Pardon Daly who was in the same locality as
Samuel Daley and who is thought to be from Rhode Island but who also
had Massachusetts connections.

CONT.value: The record of another Pardon Daily is interesting in that his name was

CONC.value: originally Pardon Relph/Ralph but his name was changed to Pardon
Daily. This is thought to be the Pardon Daly who later turned up in
Washington County, NY and was a fencesitter (I believe this was an
early name for a tax accessor) and is thought to be the father of
Samuel Daley who was an official in the government of Washington
County who had charge of construction of roads. The proof for this
connection between this Pardon

CONT.value: Daly and Samuel Daley is lacking but is interesting. I cannot recall

CONC.value: all the details, but in Rhode Island there was also a close assoiation
to an Arnold family. His wife was a Mary Hathaway. Quite a number of
years ago, I was researching with a Mrs Deloris Rutherford who had
discovered this association. Much of this information is packed away
in records since we moved about a year ago. I expect to get into them
again one of these days.

CONT.value: There was a deed located in Washington County, NY to Pardon and Sarah

CONC.value: Daley for land which had belonged to Samuel Daley and this is the
evidence for Samuel being the father of Pardon.

CONT.value: Most people who were named Pardon, seemed to have a connection to the

CONC.value: state of Rhode Island where at one time there lived a quite well known
Methodist minister by the name of Pardon Tillinghast.

CONT.value: I have met one of the ladies who submitted the information to the

CONC.value: Familyh File about Pardon Daley of Clinton County, NY being the son of
a Jacob Daily, and that was a Mrs Lynne Bitnoff who the last I heard
was living in the Sacramento area. I met her at one of the Dailey
reunions in Visalia at Mooney Grove. Her mother whose name is Luella
Dailey Black also lives in the sacramento area and who also is
extremely interested in family history. She is a direct descendant of
Parriso Dailey who settled in the Visalia

CONT.value: area and was a brother to Ed Daley who settled in the Porterville area

CONC.value: of Tulare County and the line you descend from. I suspect she would be
a third or fourth cousin to you.

CONT.value: I have wanted to write to her about the inaccurate information that

CONC.value: was submitted to the Salt Lake Family File, but have never gotten
around to it. When I last corresponded with her, I determined that she
was LDS.

CONT.value: There is still a lot of research that needs to be done on the early

CONC.value: roots of the Daley family. There is strong circumstantial evidence
that the earliest American ancestor may have been a John Daley who
lived in Rhode Island in the 1600's but proof for this is also
lacking. The origin is no doubt originally from Ireland.

CONT.value: Thanks for the message, Tim, and I plan one of these days to get back

CONC.value: to active research of this Daley line.

January 22, 1980
Mrs. Delores C. Rutherford

Dear Mrs. Rutherford:
Pamela Vogel, the Warren County historian, indicated that you were

CONC.value: inquiring about Elizabeth Herrick, who is buried in the Sunnyside
Cemetery near The Oneida, Queensbury. Her inscription indicates that
she died 18 Aug 1852, ae. 88-10-6. It is my recollection that she is
buried with members of the Hubbell family, and I find in the 1850

CONT.value: Elizabeth Herrick, 87, b. Mass., residing with Shadrack Hubbell, 64,

CONC.value: B. N.Y., Lucy Hubbell, 60, b. N.Y., and family. Is she Lucy's moter?
The hosehold is number 288/300 and was located on Moon Hill, west of
the cemetery.

CONT.value: Pam indicated that you were inquiring about Jeremiah Daly or Daily,

CONC.value: and I am wondering if Elizabeth was connected with him.

CONT.value: I have very little on the Daly family of early Queensbury and am

CONC.value: hopeful that you can add to what I here indicate: Pardon Daly was a
town officer in 1780 but is not found on later lists. Jeremiah Dailey
(51010/01010) and Samuel Daily (41010/11011) are found in the 1800
census of Queensbury. I have nothing further on Jeremiah, but Samuel
died about 1806. Letters of administration in his estate were issued
to Martha Daly and John Kinyon(?) 18 Oct. 1806 (Wash. Co. Adm.,
1:117). Samuel was listed on the 1805 assessment roll of Queensbury.

CONT.value: Patty Daly, evidently his widow, is found in the 1820 census

CONC.value: (000100/1100101). A guardianship record (Warren Co. Surr. Ct., No. 21)
recites that Samuel Daley died in 1806, intestate, with property worth
$1400. it recites that letters of administration were issued to John
Kenyon, Rufus Bates and Jonathan McComber.

CONT.value: I suspect that Samuel lived in the north section of Queensbury,

CONC.value: because that is where Jonathan McComber and Rufus Bates resided. The
latter was minister of the first Baptist church, located at the
Sunnyside Cemetery. Guardians are sought for Zina Daley (b. June 4,
1798) and Thomas Daley (b. September 16, 1796), both of Queensbury.
James Henderson is to be the guardian, and affidavits as to the ages
of the two boys are given by Pardon Daley and Asa Daley of Queensbury.
Bond was given by Henderson and Richard Bentley.

CONT.value: I find Asa Daly in the 1820 census (000010/40100/01) and Asa Daily in

CONC.value: the 1830 census, with one make 30-40, and females: 022101.

CONT.value: I am compiling information on the early families on Queensbury and

CONC.value: would be pleased to ge additional informaion on any of the persons
mentioned above.

CONT.value: Very truly yours,
John Austin
RFD 1
Gelns Falls, N.Y. 12801
January 31, 1980
Dear Mrs. Rutherford:
Thanks so much for your letter of the 25th inst. I am always glad to

CONC.value: make contact with descendants of the old families of this

CONT.value: I think there is no question but that your Asa Daly (I will spell the

CONC.value: name this way, though it is just as often found Dale, Daily, Dailey)
is a son of Samuel, who died about 1806 in Queensbury.

CONT.value: This Samuel is undougtedly the one in the Town of Argyle, Washington

CONC.value: County, in 1790, with family of one man, one boy and two females.
Three other Dalye are found listed with him. They may have been in
that part of Argyle that is today Fort Edward. The names listed near
them look like Fort Edward names to me. The other three are Parson,
William and Jeremiah. They may well be four brothers,

CONT.value: or a father and tree sons. Parson is undoubtedly Pardon. He is

CONC.value: probably the Pardon Daly who was named as fenceviewer of Queensbury in
1780. In 1783, because of the Revolution, all of the residents of
Queensbury moved out and all the houses were burned. Pardon may be the
father of these other Dalys at Argyle. It would seem that the Pardon
mentioned in Samuel's estate proceedings is a son of Samule, perhaps
named for his grandfather. I suspect that this family came from
Connecticut, which is where the Hubbells and Lewises came from, both
from New Milfrod. Do you have access to a microfilm of the Barbour
index of vital records for Connecticut? Pardon is a very unusual given

CONT.value: and it would be significant to find it in Connecticut records. I will

CONC.value: not get to Hartford, Conn., or a library with the Barbour index for a
few weeks.

CONT.value: The Warren County land records are more productive here than in the

CONC.value: usual case, since most early deeds were not recorded. I find a deed
from Joshua Harris (early immigrant from Connecticut) to Samuel Daly
"of Washington County" in 1795 of 115 acres in Lot 2 of Joshua Harris'
patent and 16-2/3 acres of Lot 1. The witnesses were Asa Brown and
Pardon Daly. (Deed G:203).

CONT.value: More information is given in mortgage by Pardon Daly to Jeremiah

CONC.value: Tubbs, both of Queensbur, for $150 of Pardon's right and interest as
an heir of Samuel Daley, deceased, in two parcels. The first is the
home farm of 85-1/2 acres, bounded north by Richard Bentley, west by
Howig(?) farm, south by Jonathan McComber and east by Reuben Seelye.
The second is the mountain lot of 115 acres, obviously

CONT.value: the parcel conveyed to Samuel by Joshua Harris, and is bounded north

CONC.value: by Hammond and Sheldon, west by David Poor, south by Elijah Dunham and
east by Joshua Harris. The witness was Daniel D. Scott (he married my
gggggf's(sic) sister). (Mortgage A;251).

CONT.value: These parcels are easily identifiable today. The home farm is located

CONC.value: on the south side of Route 149. just east of U.S. Route 9. It is today
the site of a large and flourishing travel-trailer park. The nearby
hamlet has been known for many years as French Mountain. The mountain
lot is located at the north end of Bay Road in Queensbury, near the
intersection of Lockhart Mountain Road. A later deed mentions an
exception for a schoolhouse, and an old stone schoolhouse still

CONT.value: In the same year as Pardon Daly's (1814) mortgage were two subsequent

CONC.value: mortgages, both by Pardon Daley and Lydia, his wife; Asa Daly and
Abigail, his wife; Samule Daly, Martha Sprague and Anna Daly. These
two mortgages covered the home farm. The first, for $330 was to John
L. Norton of New York City. The second, for $166, was to Dewitt
Clinton. I feel sure that this was DeWitt Clinton, governor of New
York, and these mortgages are part of a long series of mortgages of
land in this general area of Queensbury to Norton and Clinton
(Mortgages A;287, 289).

CONT.value: Samuel Daly served as a pathmaster in Queensbury in 1805.
I find a mortgage of 50 acres by Asa Daley of Queensbury to Richard

CONC.value: Wright of Kingsbury, N.Y., in 1819, being a part of the land where the
travel-trailer park is. (Mortgage C:153). This land, or at least a
protion of it, was sold by Asa Daley and Abigail, his wife, of
Queensbury, to Isaac B. Griffin for $175 in 1824 (Deed B:351).

CONT.value: There are other deeds disclosing the identity of brothers and sisters

CONC.value: of Asa: Deed B:226, Anna Daly to Timothy Goodnow, 1822, her interest
in the 115-acre mountain lot. F:476, Zina Daly of Queensbury to
Jeremiah Tubbs of Queensbury, for $200, his rights in the 115 acres
sld by Joshua Harris to Samuel Daly, (in 1823). G:204, Samule Daly of
Granville, Washington COunty, N.Y., and Betsey M., his wife, to
Jeremiah Tubbs of Queensbury , in 1832 for $400, their 3/7 interest
in the 115-acre mountain lot, excepting the one-quarter acre sold to
George Finkle on which stands a school house. L:132, Thomas Daly of
Granville and Prudence, his wife, to Gilbert Taylor of Queensbury, 1/7
of the farm of

CONT.value: which Smaule Daly, late of Queensbury, died seised(sic), being the

CONC.value: 115-acre tract.

CONT.value: I find from census indexes that Zina Daly was at Kingsbury, Washington

CONC.value: County, in 1830, and at Hartford (Between Kingsbury and Granville) in
1840 and 1850. Pardon Daly was at Mooers, Clinton County, in 1830 and
at Ellenburg, Clinton County, in 1840 and 1850. The Clinton COunty
histor says that Pardon Daly settled at Ellenburg after 1823.

CONT.value: Lewis is another family about which I know little at this point.

CONC.value: Andrew Lewis, said to be from New Milford, Conn., was at Queensbury
from 1790 until after 1810. He married Mary Wing, daughter of Abraham
and anstis (wood) Wing, and she was born 9 Nov 1760. Abraham Wing was
a Quaker and the founder of Queensbury.

CONT.value: Andrew and Mary (Wing) Lewis had a sone Charles who owned land by 1805

CONC.value: and is listed in the 1810 census (10010/20010/10), 1820 census
(210010/21010/01) and I find two Charles Lewises in the 1830 census

CONT.value: I also find advertisement in the Warren Messenger of January 1, 1829,

CONC.value: by George G. Dickinson calling for return of Charles H. Lewis,
indentured apprentice, aged 18, who had run away. Reward of one cent
offered! In additin, there was a letter at the post office in Glens
Falls for Charles H. Lewis on January 1, 1829.

CONT.value: I would appreciate a family sheet on Asa and Abigail (Herrick) Daly

CONC.value: and on Nehemiah and Elizabeth (Green) Herrick.

CONT.value: Incidentally, I believe that the Martha Sprague of the two 1814

CONC.value: mortgages to Clinton and Norton is probably the widow of Samuel Daly.
I will tyr to check this out.

CONT.value: Th Sunnyside Cemetery is located just down the road from me and is

CONC.value: very picturesque, on the shores of a small lake. My wife and I will be
buried there some day with two small boys that we lost. The Baptist
Church was gone by the 1840s'. No records known of.

CONT.value: Hope to hear from you again.
With regards,
John Austin
"During and soon after the war of 1812 the Military turnpike, between

CONC.value: Plattsburgh and Fort Covington, was put to passable condition, and
where this turnpike crossed the north branch of the Chazy River, Lewis
Ransom, who in the mean time had returned to Plattsburgh and tried the
mercantile business, erected a log tavern in 1822, and here the first
nucleus of a permanent settlement was formed.

CONT.value: "But no great advancements were made in the direction of forming homes

CONC.value: and clearing lands till Harriet Murray through her husband and agent,
made an offer of a deed of 50 acres to the first ten permanent
settlers of the town. Under the stimulus of this offer, in 1823,
Benjamin Hinds settled here, building a log house near where C. G.
Dominy now lives. Mr. Hinds was followed by Joseph Sevy, Samuel
Hasseltine, Pardon Daily, Marshall Perry, W. Jennings, Jr., Mr.
French, and EliHasseltine, all of whom received their homestead free,
according to promise. Israel R. and Edward Carpenter, two brothers,
came here in the fall and spring of '26 and '27."
IGI record number 1760733

CONT.value: "Obit for Heatha Ellen Mullins," CAMPBELL HEATHA ELLEN
born: 12/13/1878 F ARKANSAS
mother: DODSON
father: MULLINS
died: KERN 01/14/1957
age: 78 yrs
Bakersfield Californian, Tuesday, January 15, 1957
(This was very, very faded and nearly impossible to decipher.)
Campbell, Heatha Ellen - Funeral services for Mrs. Heatha Ellen

CONC.value: Campbell, 78, will be held at 10 a.m. in the Gospel Tabernacle of
Arvin, Orange and Stockton Streets under the direction of the H. R.
Borgsdorf Mortuary. The Reverends Jack Craven, Jr., Arnold Neimeyer,
and Bill Armstrong will officiate. Interment will follow in Greenlawn
Memorial Park. Mrs. Campbell was born in Russellville, Arkansas and
had been a resident of Arvin for 12 years. She died January 14 in a
Bakersfield hospital. Survivors include a daughter, Mrs. Eva Moran of
Arvin; seven sons, Roy, Fred, Rufus, Claude and John all of Arvin;
Paul of Salinas and Eugene of Milford, Utah; three sisters, Mrs. Ada
Brand of Lamont, Mrs. Ida Crites of Plainview, Arkansas and Mrs. Mary
Turner of Lubbock, Texas; three brothers, Ed Mullins of Haskell,
Okla., Elmer Mullins of Coweta, Okla., and Ted Mullins of Vian...?.. ,
Okla. 35 grandchildren and 23 great-grandchildren.
